and then what we gonna do is we're going to make pasta,  out of all the juices that come
out of it, it's going to blow you away
So first of all we're going to make the marinade, which is going to turn into the sauce
okay so we got some thyme here, we've got some basil as well
so let's just pull the thyme off of the stork, same with the basil but you can kind of just
tear off a little bit

like that, a good a pinch of salt and
pepper

it's going to roast, it's going to sweeten,

okay really important.  And you can see that sauce coming together

Let's get this pasta in here ASAP now I

see how starchy it looks
Move it around, I love that sound
that's the sound of a good pasta

just a little bit of Parmesan, little bit
of basil, that is beautiful
that really is
A mighty winter pasta sauce, I always put a few extra leaves

of basil just on top, just to tell the
story, and one last stroke
of parmesan, gorgeous and then the chicken. You're gonna get the most

title: Mediterranean Roast Chicken Pasta | Jamie Oliver

comments.text:
I just tried it.  The only alteration is that I left the lemon out (because 
my mother has some kind of allergy to them).  It's amazing.  Thanks for 
making the video!  I would have never thought of it on my own because I'm 
more comfortable cooking with soy sauce as a base ingredient.  Brilliant! 
 I'm always open to seeing more things that can be done with chicken.  This 
is exactly what I needed to help me start my new diet... Not to lose 
weight, just to eat better things. Thanks a bunch!!!  I'll be trying your 
slow-cooked beef stew next time I have time in the kitchen!﻿

comments.author: True Blue

comments.text:
75..80°C and you put it back into the oven for several minutes? No 
disrespect, but this sounds way overcooked to me. I usually get it to 65°C, 
this way it stays A LOT more juicy. 80°C is something I'd expect from the 
absolutely nuked store grill chicken.
If you're worried about bacteria:
"Essentially, the red line in this graph indicates how long a piece of 
chicken needs to be cooked at a specific temperature in order to be deemed 
safe for consumption. So, for example, we see that at 165°F (74°C), the 
chicken is safe pretty much instantaneously (hence the 165°F minimum 
internal temperature recommendation by the USDA—they are being very 
conservative and assuming you will bite into it the second it reaches that 
temp). Whereas at 140°F (60°C), the chicken needs to be held for 35 minutes 
to be safe." So if you're measuring the thickest part and it's 65°C, the 
rest of the chicken is way past that temperature for quite some time 
already. No health hazard there, but a lot more moisture and flavor.﻿
